Award.AwardTitle: Twelfth International Nanotechnology Conference on Communication and Cooperation, Leuven, Belgium

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: The proposed project seeks financial support to support student, graduates and junior, as well as faculty participation in the International Nanotechnology Conference on Communication and Cooperation (INC) to be held at IMEC Leuven, on May 10-12, 2016. The event will address research areas in nanotechnology, nano-optics and nanoelectronics. Academics and industry leaders will be able to interact on the latest issues in nanotechnology and the links with related areas, such as biotechnology, advanced materials development, microsystems and photonics will be explored. The conference will target world regional groups co-operate to implement strategic and beneficial cooperative programs to progress mankind's development through nanotechnology and its associated intellectual merits.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2016 and 2017 International Nanotechnology Conference on Communication and Cooperation Workshop held in Leuven, Belgium and Indianapolis, IN respectively, featured invited speakers and poster presenters from industry, academia, and government whopresented advances in beyond-CMOS nanoelectronics, nanoenergy, nanophotonics and issues relatedto nanosocietal implications.

Within 2 days, various speakers engaged in lively discussion related to theopportunities and challenges of Nanotechnology with a special focus on smart mobility, robotics andnanomaterials infomatics. A large emphasis on the impact of Artificial Intelligence was placed giventhe present day important and impact on application such as autonomous manufacturing,autonomous driving among others. As such this workshop had relevance to the vision of the IEEEInternational Roadmap for Devices and Systems (IRDS) and for the takeaways to be presented atconferences such as IEEE’s International Conference on Rebooting Computing.

Impact: While society benefitted from the growth of nanotechnology for computers, thebenefit came indirectly through products like Word processors, databases, and the Internet. INCorganizers believe it is becoming more important to justify ongoing advances in semiconductors interms of new applications the advances enable. The US President’s Council of Advisors on Scienceand Technology refer to applications in this way when they recommend [President’s Council ofAdvisors on Science and Technology, “Ensuring Long-Term U. S. Leadership in Semiconductors,”January 2017. Document includes a table of 14 suggested “moonshots.”] that U.S. policymakerscarefully select ambitious challenges, which [they] call ‘moonshots,’ as focal points for industry,government, and academic efforts to drive computing and semiconductor innovation forwardtogether.” As such, our workshop focused on these crosscutting applications with broader impacts toartificial intelligence, specifically deep learning and self-driving vehicles, which correspond to twomoonshots in the PCAST report (“Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning” and “Robotics,Autonomous Systems”).
